modulation I know this is for people that know software defined radio I suppose it's quite introductory but for
for people that don't it gives a good idea of what it is you start off with a carrier signal that's at 315 MHz or
433.92 MHz and then you have in the diagram I think I've shown here is a modulating sine wave signal that's your
baseband signal the data that you're transmitting so you simply modify the amplitude of the carrier signal to be
that of the bband signal um and your final result is is a modulated transmission um the envelope of that
modulated signal is your baseband so often we we're not putting
analog data across a transmission typically we're not for for this type of stuff we're putting a digital signal um
and often we just use amplitude modulation in terms of whether it's on and whether it's off um so we simply
modulate the am the the carrier wave um and then we don't modulate it um but
sometimes a lot of times we also use pulsewidth modulation so we leave the modulated signal on for a specific
amount of time and the length of that time indicates what type of symbol it is so in the diagram that I've shown here
we've got some some wide pulse widths that represents a one in this case and we've got some short pulse width and
that represents a zero so that's pulse width modulation um when you're demodulating
an unknown signal you know you don't really know what the width of these pulses are but you know that there are
wide pulses and there are short pulses so how do you know what the how wide is a wide pulse and how short is a short
pulse um I use some clustering software Pi cluster in particular um and I group
similar widths uh together um so that groups all the wide pulses together and
all the short pulses together using cluster software and then I found the mean of each of those clusters so there are two clusters the wide and the short
pulses I found the mean of those clusters and then I found the mean of
those means so that gave me a threshold to indicate whether a pulse was either wide or whether it was short and that
enabled me to to determine the symbols whether they are one or a zero so you can do this type of attack

challenge response system a rolling Code system uh is a code that when you press
the key fob every time you press it it changes what's being sent uh and the way
that this works is you have a key fob and you have your receiver and they both have a pseudo random number generator
the same algorithm on both and they're synchronized so that they can expect that so that they know what the pseudo
random number generator on the other component is so the the the key fob gets
the next random number random number from its random number generator a random number generator and transmits it
